net.floodlightcontroller.northboundapi.server
Class AbstractNBListener<CLTYPE extends AbstractNBClient>

java.lang.Object
  net.floodlightcontroller.northboundapi.server.AbstractNBListener<CLTYPE>
All Implemented Interfaces:
NBServerSocketCreator, org.openflow.northboundapi.util.NBAPICommonConstants
Direct Known Subclasses:
NorthboundAPI.NBServer
public abstract class AbstractNBListener<CLTYPE extends AbstractNBClient>
extends java.lang.Object
implements NBServerSocketCreator, org.openflow.northboundapi.util.NBAPICommonConstants

Abstract listener class for northbound server-side API.

Configuration parameters for the northbound API server are passed to the constructor from the NorthboundAPI module. In addition to the configuration parameters listed below, the ConfigParameters class from common support package adds the "SEARCH_PATH" parameter which augments the search locations when the class is asked to retrieve a file from the file system that does not represent an absolute path. By default, the home directory (as reported by the JVM) is added at the end of the search path. Also, the authenticator class is given access to the configuration parameters when initialized and may use them as one source for configuration settings (see the implementing classes for details; for example, see SimpleNBAuthenticator). Finally, if the SSL listener is used, see the NBServerSSLSupport class for additional parameters used for SSL configuration.

Note: The parameters listed in the table below must be prefaced in the floodlight configuration file with the string that identifiest parameters for the floodlight module instance that will provide the northbound API services (which may be, for example, the SENorthboundAPI class).

The following table lists the configuration parameters used directly by the AbstractNBListener class:

Configuration Parameter Name Data Type Default Description
"AUTHENTICATOR_CLASS" Java class name None. The name of the authenticator class to use for authentication. The named class must implement the NBAuthenticator interface. Each class may use its own configuration parameters.
"INPUT_BUFFER_SIZE" integer 8192 The starting size, in bytes, of the input buffer.
"INPUT_BUFFER_SIZE_MAX" integer 131072 The maximum size, in bytes, that the input buffer can be reallocated to. An entire Google Protocol Buffer message must reside in the input buffer before it can be decoded, so this parameter puts an upper bound on the size of an encoded message that can be read.
"LISTEN_ADDRESS" string None: any. The IP address or host name to bind the listen socket to.
"LISTEN_BACKLOG" integer 50 The maximum connection backlog count.
"LISTEN_PORT" integer NBAPICommonConstants.DefaultNBServerPort (29979) The port number to bind the (plain) listen socket to.
"LISTEN_TIMEOUT" integer 0 How long to wait for the accept() call to time out. A value of zero waits forever.
"LOGIN_TIMEOUT" integer 120000 (2 minutes) The login timeout, in milliseconds. A value of zero disables (login time is unlimited). The timer begins once the connection is accepted (and any SSL handshaking is complete) and constrains the time until the internal welcome message is sent (thus, it limits both how long a client may take in sending the hello message as well as completing any NB authentication protocol).
"MONITOR_REPORT_COUNTER" integer 0 The monitor report counter determines on which connection monitor cycles a report of the active connections is sent to the diagnostic log. A value of zero disables reporting. A value of one will report on every connection monitor cycle, two every other cycle, and so forth. The polling cycle time on the connection monitor is computed by the getMonitorPollTime() method which takes the smallest (non-zero) timeout of the output queue drain-wait time, the login timeout, and the ping-on-idle time, divided by MonitorPollTimeFactor (2) and bounded by the range MinimumMonitorPollTime (250) to MaximumMonitorPollTime (300000).
"OUTPUT_QUEUE_DRAIN_WAIT" integer 30000 The output queue drain-wait parameter limits how long, in milliseconds, a terminating client connection will wait for any queued output messages to be sent before abruptly closing the connection.
"OUTPUT_QUEUE_DROP_SEQUENCE" string "PACKET_IN" When the output queue (from server to client) on the server gets full (see "OUTPUT_QUEUE_LIMIT") the server must either drop messages or terminate the client. This comma-delimited list of OFTypePB subtype names identifies the order of precedence for dropping messages (first listed to last listed). An empty list means no OF messages are dropped (and the client is terminated). Messages of the first listed OF type are dropped until either the drop-to threshold is reached or there are no more messages of that type in the queue. The message dropping is repeated with each subsequent OF type listed until the drop-to threshold is reached. If, after exhausting the OF type list, the drop-to threshold has not been reached, the client connection is terminated.
"OUTPUT_QUEUE_DROP_TO" integer The queue limit. When the output queue (from server to client) on the server gets full (see "OUTPUT_QUEUE_LIMIT") the server must drop messages until the queue's message count reaches the drop-to value. If it can not, it will terminate the client's connection. Must be at least 64.
"OUTPUT_QUEUE_LIMIT" integer 8192 The output queue (from server to client) message count limit. Messages destined for a client are placed in a queue while waiting for an output thread to write them to the client's connection. If the client does not consume the messages fast enough or there is some extended communication problem, the queue can back up. This parameter limits the number of messages in the queue. If the limit is exceeded, then messages are dropped (see "OUTPUT_QUEUE_DROP_SEQUENCE") until the drop-to size is reached (see "OUTPUT_QUEUE_DROP_TO"). Must be at least 128.
"OUTPUT_BUFFER_SIZE" integer 32768 The output buffer size, in bytes. As with the input buffer, this size constrains the largest Google Protocol Buffer message that can be encoded for transport.
"PING_ON_IDLE" integer 0 If a (non-expired) connection is idle for more than this time (in milliseconds), a ping message is sent to the client in an attempt to resolve if the connection is still active/alive. A value of zero disables this feature.
"SERVICES_SELECT" string "PLAIN" Identifies which listener services to create. Must be one of the following (case insensitive) strings:
  • "PLAIN" Activate a plain socket listener.
  • "SSL" Activate an SSL socket listener; also see NBServerSSLSupport.
  • "BOTH" Activate both a plain and an SSL socket listener.
"VERSION_NORTHBOUND_MAX" integer NBAPICommonConstants.DefaultVersionNB The maximum northbound API protocol version to accept in a hello message.
"VERSION_NORTHBOUND_MIN" integer Same as max. The minimum northbound API protocol version to accept in a hello message.
"VERSION_SOUTHBOUND_MAX" integer NBAPICommonConstants.DefaultVersionSB The maximum southbound API protocol version to accept in a hello message.
"VERSION_SOUTHBOUND_MIN" integer Same as max. The minimum southbound API protocol version to accept in a hello message.

Constructor Detail

AbstractNBListener

public AbstractNBListener(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> init_params,
                          org.slf4j.Logger logger)

AbstractNBListener

public AbstractNBListener(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> init_params,
                          org.slf4j.Logger logger,
                          boolean do_start)
Create new OpenFlow Northbound API listener.

Parameters:
init_params - initialization parameter map
logger - diagnostic logging facility
do_start - if true, the startListener() method is called. Otherwise, it is up to the parent/creator to initiate the listener threads via the startListener() method (this allows for extensions to be registered before establishing listeners for client connections).
